I agree on it being confusing; I did try to name it in a helpful way.  Here's my thinking:

* cache_state: the values in the cache that we're examining; we're waiting until this thing is in sync with zk
* zk_state: the values as they are in zk

When cache_state == zk_state then the cache is in sync.  I'm open to alternatives :)

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message:
This introduces a network round trip for all node requests in the pipeline in all pipeline runs (which can be a lot). I think this may have a noticeable impact on scheduling performance in our system.

I think we usually only have to revise the priorities if some item we processed before changed in a way that requires this (I think that's only dequeued items and failed items in dependent pipelines). We could change processOneItem to return a flag if it did such a change and forward that to the next processOneItem call so we can skip this loop entirely if we don't need to revise node requests.
Yes, it uses the cache, so this is almost identical to the current code.  I don't think it's worth trying to avoid this loop right now.

AFAIK zk_nodepool.getNodeRequest() uses the local tree cache dictionary, so there shouldn't be any network roundtrips. This line is the reason we decided to add a tree cache in the first place. But I'm definitely in favour if we could find a way to avoid this loop (and don't introduce anything too complex somewhere else).

If we've got a node request registered in a build set under which conditions would it not exist in the request cache? Would that be a race between recording the ID and waiting for the cache to update?

The model.py updates hint that this might happen if request_id is None as well? However, that is response to a .get(foo) on the dict and not an iteration of the internal values.

Yes, I think that's the case where it could happen (since we don't force a cache update, we wait for ZK to notify us of the new request; that may seem silly now, but may be more reasonable when we have multiple schedulers).

Suggestion:

You can import and export zones into and out of designate using the import and export APIs. These APIs and the `zone file format`_ enable you to easily create zones and recordsets in batches and move** zones out of Designate.

** Is 'move' the right verb here? Do you export zones in order to move them?
Done.
Don't understand why recordsets are mentioned. How do they relate to zones? Does a zone consist of recordsets? (Pardon my ignorance.) :^)
Yes zones contain recordsets and each recordset is within exactly one zone.
Perhaps "Exporting Zones?"
Done
Do we describe somewhere what these different ways are?
Should 'designate' be capitalized? Not sure.
Done
I don't understand this. How does one determine the protocol of designate in the URL? And, how does one know which protocols indicate that the file is stored internally?

I've moved this explanation to the end because it's not really important. I found the design confusing and wanted to explain it as a result:
 - The zone file can be stored using different backends
 - The location will be a url and is visible on the export resource
 - The default backend has a protocol of designate:// in the url
 - There is actually only one backend implementation and that's the default one
 - it doesn't actually store the files, it generates them on demand.

I think it was originally designed to put the zone files in swift or something, but it never happened because it's such a rare issue for zone files to be that big.

I'm befuddled why there are several command examples here. The title of the section is "Zone Export," so I expect to see the example to use the `zone export create` command. But instead, I first see `openstack recordset list`. Why is that? Perhaps more explanation is needed.

I'm thinking of something like this. (I might not be correct, but you get the idea. :^) :

1. Run the `openstack recordset list` to confirm the name of the recordset that you want to export as a zone:

  $ openstack recordset list example.org.

2. Using the `openstack zone export create` command, export `example.org`:

  $ openstack zone export create example.org.

3. Using the zone ID, run the `openstack zone export show` command to identify the location of the exported zone file:

  $ openstack zone export show e75aef2c-b562-4cd9-a426-4a73f6cb82be
Done

Hmmm... couple of questions here:

A. Isn't the zone file already saved? 

B. So, the zone file that has been exported has 'tabulation?' What exactly is that? Is it a file that includes embedded tab characters? Why does having a file w/o tabulation matter?

C. Do we explain how to print w/o tabulation and then save?

A. Yes, I added that this is if you want to export-modify-import as a way of modifying the zone
B. The tabulation is the dashes and whatnot around eg. Field and Value in the other openstack commands. Including this in the result doesn't result in a valid zone file. I don't think it's a good default but that's a bug for another day.
C. It's the command below to print without tabulation. It's 'saving' a file on the local disk.

I don't understand this sentence.

Are you trying to say the following?

By default, designate automatically creates a zone export file whenever you create a zone. When you modify the zone, designate automatically updates the zone export file to reflect your changes.

Questions:
A. What is the advantage of having a zone export file automatically created when you create the zone?

B. Do we describe in another section how to change the default storage schema?

C. Why might a person want to use another schema?
I think I covered this in another answer.

Questions:

A. Can a 'single zone file' be created by exporting a zone? 

B. So, a zone consists of recordsets? Is it important to write 'a zone and all of its recordsets' instead of just writing 'a zone?'

C. Do we describe `zone file format` somewhere? If not, should we?

D. What are the variables, $ORIGIN and $TTL? I suppose most designate users/admins know what these are, or should we explain them?

A. Yes
B. Correct, I spelled it out since they're 2 different resources in Designate
C. It's a link to the wikipedia page describing the format, which is an RFC.
D. They're part of the zone file format.
Is this 'time to live?' Typically, we spell out abbreviations on their first use, unless the abbrev is super obvious like IP. This might be a question of my ignorance! 😮

So, if you want to set the TTL for a zone that you are creating through a zone file, you manually add the `TTL` setting to the zone file? Do you have the option of setting the TTL after the zone has been created?

Suggest that you rewrite this sentence in active voice:

  You must set the zone TTL using a TTL statement in the zone file.

Yep it's time to live. I'm not spelling out abbreviations that are covered in the intro doc or the managing records/zones docs because I see them as assumed knowledge once the user gets to import/export, but if that's not reasonable I can spell them out on each doc page.
Spell out abbreviation?

Instead of 'since' use 'because'.

Style Guide: "To facilitate translation, use 'since' to refer only to time. Do not use it as a synonym for "because"."
Missing a period (full stop).

Perhaps a table would be appropriate here?

-----------------------------------------------
Value of         Set by Designate 
zone file field  configuration option
---------------  ------------------------------
MNAME            Zone assigned pool**
---------------  ------------------------------
refresh value**  Random value between
                 ``default_soa_refresh_min``
                 and ``default_soa_refresh_max``
---------------  ------------------------------
min value**      ``soa_default_minimum``

To me, this sentence seems vague.

Are there multiple records in a zone? One for the zone itself and additional records? If so, then perhaps rewrite this paragraph to read:

"Designate generates the zone nameserver (NS) record based on the pool to which the zone is assigned. Other records in the zone are imported based on their assigned nameservers."

(Don't know if the second sentence is correct, it's just a guess.)

The zone itself is essentially two records: the SOA and an NS record that points to the designate Bind9 servers. This doesn't preclude users from creating other NS records within their zone, just that the zone itself won't work unless it says where its servers are.
This sentence is a bit awkward. We should reword it.

ctx

I just found another issue with even this limited transaction scope widening. 

Before consumer_types, the call graph was like
_set_allocations_for_consumer() -> _create_allocations() -> alloc_obj.replace_all() -> [retry-loop] -> _set_allocations() [starting transaction]

So before consumer_types the retry-loop in replace_all called _set_allocations() in separate transactions. Now that the transaction is started here around _create_allocation() that retry loop will call _set_allocation() within the same transaction.

We have the retry-loop to handle resource provider generation conflict. (In contrast a consumer generation conflict has no retry and raised back the the client) This could happen even if two separate consumers are created / update / deleted in parallel affecting the same resource provider (or an allocation update can race with an inventory update). This type of conflict during allocation update can be retried server side, by re-reading the rp inventory/usage and RP generation to see the result of the parallel update, and re-applying the allocation change against the new inventory. If it fits the new inventory then we are OK without asking the client to retry. 

Now with the wider transaction scope we made this retry-loop useless. The re-reading of the RP inventory happens in the same transaction in every retry attempt and due to proper transaction isolation it re-reads the old RP inventory with the old RP generation. Then if fails with the same RP generation conflict as the first time.

Here is an example of the result:

Two parallel test:
A) resize confirm -> req-dcbdd92b-c388-4a4a-b24a-216fb0d4a0fb deleting migration alloc 1582409f-6a32-457d-bfe6-26ae3b2b80b6 (instance b2d7104b-5020-4ab1-9146-0a52cd0f70a2)
B) instance boot -> req-448bea03-25a6-4d6a-a930-2f6acd7d7443 creating instance alloc ad20cf43-efa8-418b-b66b-8e0ac5655ce6

You can follow the sequence from the placement log[2]:

1) A reads alloc (inc both consumer and rp generation)
2) B creates alloc (creates an independent consumer with gen 0 but bumps the rp generation by that)
3) A tries to delete alloc -> rp generation conflict 


If we cannot start an independent transaction for the RP re-read in the retry-loop then I think we have to move the consumer update down to the retry-loop to allow the retry-loop to use separate transactions for each retry attempt.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/kuber.message: what happens in the case of KUBE_UPGRADING_NETWORKING* ?

Previously the steps were "download images", "upgrade first master", "upgrade networking", "upgrade second master", "upgrade kubelets".  So for the first two steps of an upgrade we wanted to use the old networking versions, and after that we wanted the new ones.

Now we're going to do it as "download images", "upgrade networking","upgrade first master", "upgrade second master", "upgrade kubelets".  So we only want to use the old networking versions for the first step instead of the first two steps.

neutron_lib/api/definitions/quota_check_.message:
Maybe I'm wrong but I think that this can't be shim extension as You need to define this new parameter for quota to be accepted by Neutron. Otherwise (now) when I try to send request like

    curl -g -i -X PUT http://10.120.0.30:9696/v2.0/quotas/f3ccd6bbc4e04ba4a2be183ddcc766f7 -H "Accept: application/json" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "User-Agent: python-neutronclient" -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -d '{"quota": {"network": 1000, "check_limit": true}}'


I got error:

    {"NeutronError": {"type": "HTTPBadRequest", "message": "Unrecognized attribute(s) 'check_limit'", "detail": ""}}


I tested without that patch in Neutron-lib but as it's shim extension I don't think it would change anything really.

This is an API extension but quota controller does not uses any API definition. All extension will inherit from "extensions.APIExtensionDescriptor" and will define "api_definition", pointing to a file from this directory.

When we start Neutron server, we retrieve all resources [1][2]. That includes the QuotaSetsController. But this controller does not have a defined API. During the extension load process, some resources can be marked with "register_quota" [3].

When the quota controller is called to set a value, the API attributes are updated, that means EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0 is updated. Example of what this variable contains when updated: https://paste.opendev.org/show/809228/

To sum up: "check_limit" is a new API parameter but not defined in the n-lib API definitions. If you download [4] (that includes the n-lib bump), you'll be able to execute this HTTP request.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/c39896bd0775de032c471012deaff0edd82153c4/neutron/pecan_wsgi/startup.py#L61
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/c39896bd0775de032c471012deaff0edd82153c4/neutron/api/extensions.py#L299-L306
[3]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/c39896bd0775de032c471012deaff0edd82153c4/neutron/api/v2/resource_helper.py#L65-L66
[4]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/801470

\notes from the collab review session... 

This isn't really necessary; if a nondisruptive share server migration is sought, there's no way that can be fulfilled without retaining the network allocations. So, if a driver accepts a nondisruptive share server migration requests, we can always assume ip reuse is supported.
Done

\notes from the collab review session... 

Agree with ganso that this option is unnecessary; however, you could enhance the current share server migration workflow to simplify it:

When a server has been successfully migrated, there should be no reason to leave it behind. The current logic in the code sets the server to Inactive and the share server is cleaned up in one of three waus:

1) If CONF.delete_share_server_with_last_share is True, the share manager deletes the server
2) If CONF.automatic_share_server_cleanup (and CONF.unused_share_server_cleanup_interval) are set, the share manager reaps inactive share servers when time comes
3) The administrator lists and deletes the inactive share server. 

We can rethink this - it makes sense to have unused share servers lying around for a bit to optimize share creation time with reuse - however, this sort of reuse doesn't make sense for share servers that have been migrated. Administrators migrate for a specific reason and they should never expect any cruft to be left behind once a migration has been completed. So, unlike any other case, we should actively delete/cleanup the vestigial source share server immediately after the share server migration completes - no need to check for any configuration option or wait for a reaping interval/manual intervention.
Done

How does this work?

User has requested a migration with nondisruptive=False, driver responds with nondisruptive=True, but, we don't create a new share server on the backend because the driver told us it supports a nondisruptive share server migration - so this allocation has to be created - but, how will the driver know to set the network interfaces based on this network allocation?

> but, how will the driver know to set the network interfaces based on this network allocation?
In this case, the driver would need to set up the allocations either in the migration start or in the migration complete operations. The drivers can check if there are network allocations in the destination share server. If there are some, just set up the new network interfaces. If there aren't, there is nothing to do, since the interfaces are being reused :)

> Shouldn't the driver disallow nondisruptive migration unless explicitly asked for?
There might scenarios like in the SVM Migrate where the migration mechanism will always reuse the share server regardless if the requested params is 'nondisruptive' or not... So if we create the share server even when the driver reports nondisruptive migration, a share server would be created and it wouldn't be used for anything, because the backend is really moving the share server across backends.
Let's try to picture the scenario where we disallow nondisruptive migration when it wasn't requested by the admin:
- Admin requests a disruptive share server migration
- Driver responds it can do it nondisruptively
- We ignore the driver's response and send a request to create the share server and net interfaces
- We set up the share server in the backend
- Migration actually moves the share server across backends and doesn't even touch the source backend
The share server that was created won't be useful in this case... This scenario of migration where we set up a new share server in the back end seems more like a replication I'd say :)

This error isn't surfaced before the migration begins? 
Should the driver disable v4  before starting the migration so this situation doesn't occur. 

If v4 is enabled, and nondisruptive migration is requested, perhaps you can deny the nondisruptive migration capability during migration check; since its not possible to know if clients are connected with v4.0. wdyt?

Thanks for the context and the explanation.

> considering that it will be turned off before the migration starts


Yeah, i was thinking that if it can be and needs to be turned off, the driver should handle it. I understand there's no straightforward way to know if v4.0 is being "used"... 

Just so I understand, Does issuing a svm migration with "check_only" check that the storage systems involved are AFF and that the vserver has NFS v4.0 version enabled when the migration began?

> This error isn't surfaced before the migration begins? 
Yes, it should fail in the check... Administrators could either use the NFS versions configuration parameters in their backends, or if they are completely sure that there is not anyone using NFS v4.0, they could disable this in ONTAP and the check/migration start operations should work properly if this is the only issue.

> If v4 is enabled, and nondisruptive migration is requested, perhaps you can deny the nondisruptive migration capability during migration check; since its not possible to know if clients are connected with v4.0. wdyt?
This is a good point... I have even discussed this with Felipe in the past :)... The only thing that made us to keep it like this is: There isn't a way to ensure that if we turn the nfs v4.0 off the check will pass, because it failed because the NFS v4.0, but the check only shows one issue at a time, so if there is another thing blocking the check, we won't know...
So let's consider the following scenario:
- Admin request a nondisruptive migration for a share server that has NFS v4.0 enabled
- Source or dest cluster aren't AFF
- NetApp driver identifies that NFS v4.0 is enabled and says it is okay (returns that the migration is compatible), considering that it will be turned off before the migration starts
- Admin thinks the migration is okay, and starts it
- In the migration start, we turn NFS 4.0 off and send the migration request to ONTAP
- ONTAP Fails saying that either source or destination clusters aren't AFF...
This issue could be pretty annoying to admins, because we previously told them that the migration would be feasible, but when they requested the migration, it faled alledging other issue.
And there is no way to skip the NFS v4.0 validation... That's the reason we decided to follow with this approach...
I have even implemented disabling the nfs v4.0 in the past, but the above scenario happened.
NetApp intends to implement SVM migrate for nfs v4.0 in a near future though, so when that happens, this problem will be avoided :)

Ah, i understand that better now; I would expect the user (cloud administrator in this case) performs the check operation until it succeeds (correcting incompatibilities each time) before initiating a migration..

Yes, only performing this request with "check_only" will do all validations that are done before a migration is started, and return if the migration is possible or not.  The only problem as I mentioned is that each time it will raise one single error, even though there might be more than one.

Do not need to care about the guest CPU arch, based on libvirt realization: https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2020-September/msg00328.html
A link to docs or some other place that this limitation is discussed would be appreciated

Done
Done
Done

Linking to a libvirt patch thread is not operator-friendly and can be too much info.

I'd rewrite the error as:

    "On AArch64 hosts, source and destination host CPUs 
    are compared to check if they're compatible (the only
    use-case supported by libvirt for Arm/AAarch64)"
Done

First, let's remove some confusion with the vague phrase "CPU comparison" — it can mean comparing guest CPU with host CPU; or one host CPU with another host CPU:

The general use case of libvirt's compareCPU() API is to allow comparing a guest CPU to a host CPU.  However, for AArch64, the _only_ use case libvirt supports is to allow comparing host CPU with a destination CPU — this is accomplished with the help of this patch[1].

So what we're talking about here, in context of AArch64, is comparing source _host_ CPU to destination _host_ CPU, so as to prevent a guest from migrating to a completely different host.

                                     * * *

For AArch64, in the past we skipped[2] _guest_ CPU to host CPU comparison (the "traditional" use case) check for AArch64 for two main reasons, and these reasons are still valid:

- There are lots of vendors making different AArch64 CPUs, and they're all not easily comparable because they all differ in various ways.

- QEMU AArch64 developers themselves recommend that using 'host-passthrough' is  the way to run KVM guests on AArch64.

In sum, for AArch64, (a) guests should use 'host-passthrough'; and (b) src host to dest host CPU comparison only makes sense to know about _host_ CPU compatibility, but you will not get any CPU config that you can give to a guest.


[1] https://listman.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2020-September/msg01391.html — Modify virCPUarmCompare to perform compare actions

stx-audit-helm/stx-audit-helm/files/audi.message:
Do you have any information on how large the audit log files are expected to be? It looks to me like this will rotate daily with no consideration for size.

Is there a risk that one day could produce a huge log file that won't get rotated until the next day and could cause problems?
I think a size limit would be reasonable.  How often does logrotate run to check the size?

Let's follow existing patterns so that we can control the maximum impact on the platform filesystems and specify a size and max number of rotations. Can we start with 
  
  size 10M
  start 1
  rotate 20

and adjust as needed.

Thanks for the info. I was mainly concerned about the possibility of a single day log file reaching an absurd size, but this might be very unlikely.
It could be worth adding a size value just as a preventive measure. 

Perhaps other reviewers will have an opinion on this.

I set "daily" rotation to conform to a DISA requirement I found: "If it is not rotated daily and moved to another location, then there is more of a chance for the compromise of audit data by malicious users". Some other article had "weekly" rotation for auditd, which would allow for very large log files, so not a good choice. On my test system I have aprox 15M of compressed audit logs in one day. I can add a size value also to make sure it does not exceed it. We do not want to rotate too often either.
I don't know the exact frequency, but I recall from the last time I added logrotate stuff that it is quite often. Like a file will be rotated within minutes of reaching the threshold.

logrotate configuration from "/etc/logrotate.conf" and "/etc/cron.d/logrotate" does not have entries for rotating when a max size is reached. My testing has confirmed that. So unless we make changes there, logs will rotate only for hourly, daily and weekly configurations. I do not see other logs, like, cert-mon.log, that has 10M max size that it rotates after 10M is exceeded.

In my previous comment I made a typo that I'd like to correct it. Where I used "M" for file size I should have used "K".

I have applied the changes that Bob suggested. I also replaced "size" with "maxsize" so I can keep "daily" rotation as well to ensure rotation still can occur, whichever limit comes first, as suggested by Chris. "size" and "daily" are mutually exclusive.

For auditd logs, size 10M will be reached in 2 min, so rotating 20 times will only cover 40 min of logs. In 24h, for 20 rotations we would need a size of 360M.
However, as I mentioned above, size does not trigger log rotation in the current logrotate cron job config. Hourly and daily do work though.
Other logs that have "size" set do not get rotated either.

Could it be because of this config in "/etc/cron.d/logrotate":

# m h dom mon dow user  command
## Commenting out cron. Replaced by logmgmt daemon
#*/10 * * * * root /etc/logrotate.cron

zuul/nodepool.py.message: The election is busy looping if you ever set the event in line 137 as you don't clear it anywhere. That's probably the reason for the "too many open files" issue.
Stats should be inside the election_won block.
We still need to remove the internal requests cache for SOS.

I think this races with _electionWon() above. As there is a period of time between setting self.election_won to False on line 113 and winning the election on line 76 which causes electionWon() to be called and set self.election_won back to True on line 100.

If there is a watcher event context switch while that period of time is happening then election_won would be False and this is skipped.

That's okay because when we win the election, the first thing we do is set the flag to allow new events to proceed.  Then we iterate over every request and submit a NodesProvisionedEvent for each.  This may produce duplicate events, which is what makes the race okay.

We might miss emitting some timing statistics, but that's okay too.

In my head I keep thinking of the system_id as a scheduler id but really it is intended to identify an entire zuul system. This would potentially be problematic if it was scheduler specific as we could starve requests but is fine as an entire system identifier.
Do we always need to set this otherwise after the first time through a won election we'll wait() indefinitely and not process further requests?

That's actually the intended behavior.  This is really a thread-shifting situation, because we get this callback from kazoo, but we only want one scheduler to emit these events.  We don't want to run an election for every event (that's a lot of zk traffic) so we can't run the election in this method; instead we want one scheduler to semi-persistently be in charge of emitting the events.  So we just check that we've won the election here.

But we want something to continuously try to win the election, so we have a thread dedicated to doing that.  Once it's won the election though, there's nothing for it to do, so it just waits for this code to tell it there was an error and it should try again (or for shutdown).

There is another alternative -- we could make an internal queue of events and push them onto the queue here and pop them from the queue in the electionWon method.  But if we did that we would have one extra queue (I heard you liked queues so here's a queue for your queue); this seemed simpler to me at the time.

zuul/zk/event_queues.py.message: I think we should move this to zuul/zk/nodepool.py

It's an election to decide who submits events to a zk event queue, just like the one above.  I thought having them in proximity made sense because they are so similar.  Also, zk/nodepool.py is the file that holds the routines for implementing the nodepool protocol, and this is Zuul related.  If we move it anywhere, it should be zuul/nodepool.py.  Or if it really needs to be in zk/ then it should probably be a new file.  I can move it if you still think it doesn't make sense here, but I'd love to know why, so I can keep my mental map of what the different files are for up to date.

I've seen zk/nodepool.py more as a place for all nodepool+ZK related code, not necessarily only the protocol implementation. But I'm totally fine with keeping it here. It just didn't quite fit my mental map when looking at it :)

zuul/zk/nodepool.py.message:
The callback called here emits a NodeRequestComplete event into the ZK queue.

In a subsequent change, we use an election to avoid having multiple schedulers emit that event (because it's silly and wasteful for all of them to emit the same event).  However, there's a race condition if the election winner changes, so we can emit duplicate events in some cases, and the schedulers accept that.  Ultimately the event handler in the main loop is idemptotent for this.

But this particular condition is about preventing this single scheduler from emitting that event more often than necessary.  This method is called every time the node object in ZK changes (which could be something innocuous like the request priority changed).  So we only call the callback that emits the event if the state changed (for the same reason, it's silly to emit a node request completed event every time the request itself changes).

This will always get called when our internal tree cache changes.  Even if our cache is stale because of a disconnection, the tree cache will refresh everything on reconnection.  Whether the refresh at that point or some point in the future has the request set to completed, we should see it.  The one case we can't handle this way is:

1) Sched A has a watch, ZK sends the notification.
2) Before it arrives/is processed, sched A crashes.
3) Sched B comes online.

In that case, no one has received the notification of the update.  That's why we emit events when a scheduler starts up.

4) Sched B iterates over all completed node requests and emits (possibly duplicate) node completed events.

I think that's all in the next change (and that should be okay because none of it is necessary until there are 2 schedulers; this code is fine with only one).

We are using the comparison between old state in the local cache and current state in zookeeper to determine if the callback should be called as we don't want to call the callback multiple times. Does this work if for some reason our cache is stale or multiple schedulers are getting these events?

Would it make sense to make the callback idempotent if it isn't already?

(2) It's easier for readers if you put the name of your driver first.  So I'd suggest doing this like:

   ---
   features:

     _ |

src/tests/tests.yaml.message:
This block should become (copy-pasted from charm-designate):

    tests_options:
      force_deploy:
        # NOTE(lourot): this is needed because the NRPE charm isn't available on
        # non-LTS Ubuntu series. See lp:1933643
        - groovy-victoria
        - hirsute-wallaby

I think I know what the problem is, because this is happening to me locally as well when running 'tox -e func-smoke' (validating bionic-stein). This hangs on

    Setting {'data-port': 'br-ex:fa:16:3e:1f:93:a8'} on neutron-gateway

Because we use juju_wait() in order to wait for the all units to become ready after setting the data-port: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/blob/master/zaza/openstack/utilities/openstack.py#L1003

But at that moment you still have the nrpe units in blocked state saying "Nagios server not configured or related". So either you are missing an earlier Zaza configure step that would properly set up nrpe, or may you indeed are missing a relation to a nagios charm? Or maybe there is a config option to nrpe to have it ignore the lack of Nagios?

In fact this is the first time we are having both neutron-gateway and nrpe in a charm test gate it seems, so that's why this has never been an issue in other gates with nrpe in their bundles.

So yes the solution will be either the nrpe charm has an option to ignore the lack of Nagios or you'll have to add a nagios charm to the bundles. Or maybe there is a way to tell zaza-openstack-tests to not use juju_wait() in this case. Please research in these directions.

cinder/context.py.message: I'm not intimately familiar with versioned objects, but what happens if you ask for an attribute that doesn't exist? Is there a way to except something more specific here, especially since we're swallowing whatever is raised?

I initially tried using hasattr() to pre-test for the attributes, but that in turn caused some lazy-loads like [1] to fail.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/objects/volume.py#L415

So then I'd need to catch that one, and the code started to get way more involved than I intended. In the end, I decided to keep it simple. If the attribute is available, then fine, we grab it. If it isn't available then we really don't need to distinguish the reason why.

I don't know how you want to handle this, but for Xena we only have 3 of the 5 eventual personas:

1. project-reader
2. project-member
3. "system-admin"

"system-admin" has all the powers to administer the cinder system, but since we aren't recognizing scope in Xena, it's basically any user in a project who has the 'admin' role (so, basically, what you have as the legacy_admin, below).

In Yoga, we'll be rewriting the policies so that your system_admin at line 66 will be the "system-admin", and we'll add in the project-admin and system-reader.

and then we update:

  DEPRECATED_SINCE = versionutils.deprecated.YOGA

when we start working on system-scope things next release isn't that going to change the deprecation warning out from under us?

At that point, won't we have to go back anyway and add deprecated_reason to everything we've done in Xena before we can update DEPRECATED_SINCE?

I think my concern is this:

  # DEPRECATED
  # "volume:attachment_create":"" has been deprecated since X in favor
  # of "volume:attachment_create":"rule:xena_system_admin_or_project_mem
  # ber".

And then in the next release:

  # DEPRECATED
  # "volume:attachment_create":"rule:xena_system_admin_or_project_member
  # " has been deprecated since Y in favor of

We're saying the volume:attachment_create was deprecated in X, but then we're saying it was deprecated in X? Or is that because we're treating it as an entirely separate deprecation?

I just say the default value being passed into the CinderDeprecatedRule object and that raised a concern is we change the default value and then accidentally change the messaging to operators.

Ok - so these are treated as two separate deprecations? In Xena it will be:

  deprecated: ""
  new: "role:admin or (role:member and project_id:%(project_id)s)"

In Yoga it will be:

  deprecated: "role:admin or (role:member and project_id:%(project_id)s)"
  new: "(role:admin and system_scope:all) or (role:member and project_id:%(project_id)s)"


To clarify, if operators are 1.) using the defaults and 2.) allowing people with custom roles to create things in cinder, they must update those role assignments before they deploy Yoga's default policies otherwise their users will have broken flows, right?

Well, once Yoga opens, all current CinderDeprecatedRules will either be deleted or have their check_str updated (at which point since-Yoga will be accurate), or they will be new CinderDeprecatedRules (for all the "rule:admin_api" policies, which were not deprecated in Xena), and since-Yoga will be accurate for them also.  I think the Yoga deprecated reason above will be accurate for everything as well.

Sorry to be obtuse.  I think that everything will be fine. 😊  These sample policy files were generated using the strategy outlined here and I think they look OK?

xena: https://paste.opendev.org/show/808268/
yoga: https://paste.opendev.org/show/808269/

OK, thanks, now I have a better handle on your concern.

To answer your question, we're treating these as two separate deprecations, and the indicator for this is the change in deprecated_since.

(I think in the context of the "Implementation Schedule" in the policy matrix [0] that this will make sense to operators, namely, that we're making a change in X and another change in Y as part of a change that's happening over multiple cycles.)

So basically what's going on is that an operator looks at the X sample file you quoted above, and what we're saying is:

> Since the X release, we are preferring that you use
> "volume:attachment_create":"rule:xena_system_admin_or_project_member",
> instead of
> "volume:attachment_create":""
> and further, while "volume:attachment_create" may work for unrestricted users in X, it's not guaranteed to work that way in Y.  Instead, it will follow the "xena_system_admin_or_project_member" rule.

The next release happens.  The operator looks at the Y sample file you quoted above, and now what we're saying is:

> Since the Y release, we are preferring that you use
> "volume:attachment_create":"rule:system_admin_or_project_member"
> instead of
> "volume:attachment_create":"rule:xena_system_admin_or_project_member",
> and that second rule is not guaranteed to be defined in the next release (Z).

I think what's kind of  confusing here is that we have two different kinds of deprecation happening:

(1) The default value of a policy has changed, and you need to be aware of this (though you may not need to do anything).  This is what's happening in the X example above.

(2) A rule we provide (e.g., "rule:volume_extension:volume_type_encryption" or "rule:admin_api") will not be defined in the next release.
The only way I could see how to do this is a roll-your-own strategy [1] which gives you a sample config that seems pretty clear: https://paste.opendev.org/show/808414/

I think I need to add these roll-your-own deprecations (in X, i.e., now) to the RuleDefaults we no longer intend to include in Y.

If we generate a sample policy file, is it going to say foo is deprecated since Xena, and then say it's deprecated as of Yoga when we updated DEPRECATED_SINCE to versionutils.deprecated.YOGA?

Update, I think I understand -- tell me if this is right: we only need to put Change objects in the change cache, not other Ref objects.  (The reason we have a change cache at all is because of the cost of asking the code review system for information about it; there is no cost for non-change refs since the code review system doesn't have any extra information, so no need to cache.)

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message: Regardless of how we answer the question below -- why don't we move this logic into setChangeAttributes so that we can just call that method here (and in similar call sites) and it can decide whether it needs to do something with ZK or just call "setattr"?
We are doing it unconditionally, but for our use case it only makes sense for Tags, so I think it would be fine to do that conditionally.

Yes, it's specifically for Tag refs -- see commit 04ac8287b62f5d66356977d971c2518836615086

Mechanically, containing_branchs for tags is a lot like files for changes.  It's an inherent property of the change, but our code review systems don't supply it so we ask the merger for it when needed and then augment the change object.

So IIUC, because this does not apply to Change objects, we don't need the commented-out code.

However, every scheduler that processes this pipeline is going to need access to the list of containing branches of the tag, so we either need to put the ref in the change cache so it can benefit from the same system, or put this information on the queue item instead.

I feel like putting all refs in the change cache might be better because it's more consistent with changes.
Is it correct that we are setting the `containing_branches` attribute independent of whether it's a Tag or some other ref? If it's only needed for tags we should make this conditional.
Ok, lets put all the refs in the change cache.

This looks like it will correctly handle the CONNECTED -> SUSPENDED -> CONNECTED transition. However I think this endless loop will deadlock the executor in case we really loose the session (in which case we will loose the lock on the build request and the scheduler should re-try the entire build). I think we need to check here as well if we lost the zk session and stop if we lost it.

We could add a connection lost listener to the executor which triggers an abort of this loop. I think is useful anyway since if we lost the session we can abort all currently running builds as well.

cgcs-patch/cgcs-patch/cgcs_patch/base.py.message: Do we also need to do the same thing for ipv6, or is localhost and iptables related stuff completely different here.

Hi Al, I don't believe so.  The upstream k8s commit made the change explicitly for IPv4 and has the comment "ipv6 doesn't have this issue" (in relation to the security fix).  In addition, the kernel fw implementation for IPv4 (iptables) is separate from IPv6 (ip6tables), so the DROP !localhost -> localhost rule wouldn't apply here.  In fact, the upstream commit uses 127.0.0.1 rather than the localhost name while installing the rule. Having said that, I did not explicitly test an upgrade from k8s 1.18.1 -> 1.19.13 on an IPv6 setup; I thought it best not to make the same change here for the v6 outgoing socket setup.
